Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Robust Algorithms for Multi-Task Learning of Spatio-Temporal Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent years have witnessed an explosive growth of data collected from different geographical locations at different time points, known as spatio-temporal data. Spatio-temporal data are generated from a wide array of sensing technology and through scientific simulations. Analysis of the big spatio-temporal data is crucial as it supports key applications of national importance such as environmental sustainability, healthcare, and national security. However, in order to realize its full benefits, there are major analytical and computational challenges that must be overcome. This interdisciplinary research seeks to overcome some of the challenges by developing innovative prediction algorithms. As proof of concept, the algorithms will be incorporated into an ensemble prediction system developed by one of the principal investigators to enhance the nation's seasonal drought forecast capability. Benchmark data sets will be created and made available to other researchers for evaluating their algorithms. The project web page (http://www.cse.msu.edu/~ptan/project/mtl) will be used to disseminate experimental results, published papers, and software developed in this project. The graduate students who participate in the project will be trained to conduct cutting edge multidisciplinary research as next-generation data scientists.

There are many spatio-temporal prediction tasks that involve solving multiple related sub-problems. Rather than designing the prediction model for each sub-problem independently, it would be desirable to solve the prediction tasks jointly by exploiting their spatio-temporal autocorrelations, thus making it a natural fit for applying a multi-task learning paradigm. This proposal centers around the following four key contributions to address the challenges of applying multi-task learning to large-scale spatio-temporal data. First, a space-efficient online multi-task learning algorithm, with theoretically proven convergence rates, will be developed to handle the massive volume of data. Second, a deep learning framework will be developed to extract salient spatio-temporal features for multi-task predictions. Third, novel multi-task learning algorithms will be developed to deal with multi-scale variables, which are becoming increasingly prevalent with the proliferation of high-resolution sensors and simulation data generated at increasingly finer resolutions. Finally, the proposed algorithms will be applied to various spatio-temporal domains, including climate and environmental sciences. Overall the proposed research will advance current state-of-the-art by developing innovative prediction algorithms that consider the inherent spatial and temporal variability of the data and provide solutions with high predictive accuracy and learning efficiency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary of Project Outcomes

Recent years have witnessed an explosive growth of data collected for different geographical locations at multiple time points. These spatio-temporal data, as they are commonly known, are valuable for constructing prediction models that will support key applications of national importance such as environmental monitoring, precision agriculture, and healthcare. The overarching goal of this project is to develop novel machine learning algorithms that will address the computational challenges of building reliable models from large-scale spatio-temporal data. As many of the prediction tasks involve making predictions simultaneously for multiple locations or at multiple time points, our project aims to develop innovative multi-task learning (MTL) methods that exploit the inherent relationships among the different tasks to enhance their overall prediction results.

Our project has contributed to advancing current state-of-the-art in spatio-temporal MTL along the following directions. First, we develop an efficient online learning algorithm to scale-up the MTL approach to handle massive datasets. Specifically, an online tensor decomposition method called WISDOM was proposed to extract a set of interpretable, spatial and temporal latent factors that will be used to incrementally train an ensemble of prediction models over space and time. The work received the best paper award at the 2016 IEEE International Conference on Big Data. In addition, our team has developed an online learning algorithm called OMuLeT for long-term forecasting of spatial trajectory data. The algorithm was successfully applied to the hurricane path prediction problem.

Another major contribution of this project is in the development of deep learning architectures for MTL in spatio-temporal data. First, we proposed an effective algorithm for multi-location prediction using a novel graph convolutional LSTM architecture that combines the strengths of LSTM for time series prediction with graph convolutional networks for modeling spatial relationships in the data. Instead of imposing a fixed graph structure based on the spatial proximity between locations, our method treats the spatial adjacency matrix as a model parameter that can be efficiently learned by enforcing sparsity constraints on the matrix. Second, we introduced a hierarchical LSTM framework for capturing different types of temporal dependencies in time series forecasting and showed how it was successfully applied to the long-term sea-surface temperature forecasting problem. Third, we investigated the different ways of employing convolutional methods to learn the spatial dependencies for predictive modeling applications. Our finding has led to development of a novel spatio-temporal deep learning method that applies convolution on both the predictor variables as well as model parameters to enhance its prediction accuracy.

Third, we proposed MTL algorithms for multi-scale data, which is increasingly important with the proliferation of spatio-temporal data generated at varying spatial and/or temporal resolutions. Our contributions include the development of MUSCAT, an online, multi-tensor decomposition method for multi-scale data and a novel MTL framework with group-level feature disaggregation to improve predictive performance on nested, multi-scale data. The latter framework is also useful to infer cross-scale interactions present in the multi-scale data. A cross-scale interaction refers to the joint effect between the local and group-level features and have provided a basis for understanding complex environmental and ecological processes such as climate change, land-use/land-cover change, and invasive species.

Finally, the proposed methods were successfully applied to a wide variety of applications, including weather forecasting, sea-surface temperature prediction, hurricane trajectory and intensity prediction, drought prediction, crime prediction, soil moisture downscaling as well as activity recognition from multi-modal sensor data.

A summary of the outcomes of this project are as follows:

- 17 peer-reviewed publications in high-impact journals and conferences such as TKDE, KDD, AAAI, IJCAI, and ICDM.

- 1 invited keynote presentation on multi-task learning for spatio-temporal data at the 13th International Workshop on Spatial and Spatiotemporal Data Mining, held in conjunction with the IEEE International Conference on Data Mining (ICDM 2018).

- 3 poster presentations at American Geographical Union (AGU) fall meeting to broaden the impact of this research.

- More than 10 software packages along with their respective datasets disseminated on GitHub repository.

- 1 project website providing extensive information related to the project, including software, papers, as well as educational materials on spatio-temporal data mining based on the data mining course taught by the PI at MSU. A new repository of spatio-temporal datasets has also been created.

- 1 graduated female PhD student in computer science, who has since joined the industry as a Research Scientist, with three other PhD students (2 in computer science and 1 in geography) who are expected to graduate by Fall 2020 or Summer 2021. The thesis dissertation for each student contains at least two chapters from the results of this project.
